/* @jsx mdx */ import React from 'react' import { mdx } from '@mdx-js/react' /* @jsx mdx */ import { Playground, Props } from "docz"; import { Button, ButtonDropdown, DropdownToggle, DropdownMenu, DropdownItem, ButtonGroup, ButtonToolbar, UncontrolledButtonDropdown } from "reactstrap"; const makeShortcode = name => function MDXDefaultShortcode(props) { console.warn("Component " + name + " was not imported, exported, or provided by MDXProvider as global scope") return
}; const layoutProps = { }; const MDXLayout = "wrapper" export default function MDXContent({ components, ...props }) { return

{`Buttons`}

{`Button Tags`}

{`The `}{`.btn`}{` classes are designed to be used with the `}{`\n\n'} __scope={{ props: this ? this.props : props, Playground, Props, Button, ButtonDropdown, DropdownToggle, DropdownMenu, DropdownItem, ButtonGroup, ButtonToolbar, UncontrolledButtonDropdown }} mdxType="Playground"> 

{`





PRIMARY
SECONDARY
TERTIARY





`}

{`Group Buttons`}

{`Note that these buttons have spaces between them. You can also group them with the `}{`.btn-group`}{` class. Here is an example.`}

{`Wrap a series of buttons with `}{`.btn`}{` in `}{`.btn-group`}{`.`}

{`Note: Assistive Technology`}{` In order for assistive technologies (such as screen readers) to convey that a series of buttons is grouped, an appropriate role attribute needs to be provided. For button groups, this would be `}{`role="group"`}{`, while toolbars should have a `}{`role="toolbar"`}{`.`}

{`In addition, groups and toolbars should be given an explicit label, as most assistive technologies will otherwise not announce them, despite the presence of the correct role attribute. In the examples provided here, we use `}{`aria-label`}{`, but alternatives such as `}{`aria-labelledby`}{` can also be used.`}

\n \n \n \n'} __scope={{ props: this ? this.props : props, Playground, Props, Button, ButtonDropdown, DropdownToggle, DropdownMenu, DropdownItem, ButtonGroup, ButtonToolbar, UncontrolledButtonDropdown }} mdxType="Playground"> 
{`

    
    
    


`}

{`Call to Action Button`}

{`Call to Action (CTA) buttons are typically used in banners and carousels, or anywhere we would want the user to action a particular item. They may also be used on busy backgrounds to increase visibility. There is a limit of one CTA button per page and should be used for the most prominent action on the page. For additional buttons, please resort to one of the default styles. `}{`There is a limit of one CTA button per page and should be used for the most prominent action on the page.`}

{`CTA Buttons`}

\n Primary\n\n\n\n

`}

{`Sizes`}

{`Fancy larger or smaller buttons? Add `}{`.btn-lg`}{` or `}{`.btn-sm`}{` for additional sizes.`}

{`Active state`}

{`Buttons will appear pressed (with a darker background, darker border and inset shadow) when active. There’s no need to add a class to `}{`\n\n'} __scope={{ props: this ? this.props : props, Playground, Props, Button, ButtonDropdown, DropdownToggle, DropdownMenu, DropdownItem, ButtonGroup, ButtonToolbar, UncontrolledButtonDropdown }} mdxType="Playground"> 

{`


`}

{`Disabled state`}

{`Make buttons look inactive by adding the disabled boolean attribute to any `}{`\n\n\n\n'} __scope={{ props: this ? this.props : props, Playground, Props, Button, ButtonDropdown, DropdownToggle, DropdownMenu, DropdownItem, ButtonGroup, ButtonToolbar, UncontrolledButtonDropdown }} mdxType="Playground"> 

{`

{`Disabled Call To Action Button`}

\n Primary\n\n\n\n\n'} __scope={{ props: this ? this.props : props, Playground, Props, Button, ButtonDropdown, DropdownToggle, DropdownMenu, DropdownItem, ButtonGroup, ButtonToolbar, UncontrolledButtonDropdown }} mdxType="Playground"> 
{`


`}

{`Link functionality caveat`}

{`The `}{`.disabled`}{` class uses `}{`pointer-events: none`}{` to try to disable the link functionality of `}{``}{`, but that CSS property is not yet standardized. In addition, even in browsers that do support `}{`pointer-events: none`}{`, keyboard navigation remains unaffected, meaning that sighted keyboard users and users of assistive technologies will still be able to activate these links. So to be safe, add a `}{`tabindex='-1'`}{` attribute on these links (to prevent them from receiving keyboard focus) and use custom JavaScript to disable their functionality.`}

{`Disabled buttons using the `}{``}{` element behave a bit differently:`}

  • It doesn't support the disabled attribute, so you must add the .disabled class to make it visually appear disabled.
  • Some future-friendly styles are included to disable all pointer-events on anchor buttons. In browsers which support that property, you won’t see the disabled cursor at all.
  • Disabled buttons should include the aria-disabled='true' attribute to indicate the state of the element to assistive technologies.

## Drop variations Trigger dropdown menus to the left of elements by adding `.dropleft .dropright .dropup` to the parent element. Dropup Another Action Another Action Dropleft Another Action Another Action Dropleft Another Action Another Action

## Split Button Similarly, create split button dropdowns with virtually the same markup as single button dropdowns, but with the addition of `.dropdown-toggle-split` for proper spacing around the dropdown caret. We use this extra class to reduce the horizontal padding on either side of the caret by 25% and remove the `margin-left` that’s added for regular button dropdowns. Those extra changes keep the caret centered in the split button and provide a more appropriately sized hit area next to the main button. ### Split Button and Dropdown Divider
